nodes.bodyText: These two fields (filter and languageCode) aren't required that the user set to run, so we should inline them in the sample below instead.
We should also add links to the docs for these resources, so users know other options that are available for them.

I inlined them and added comments to provide context on other options, but couldn't really find a good link for more info on filters. I got the supported filter types from here: https://cloud.google.com/dlp/docs/reference/rpc/google.privacy.dlp.v2#google.privacy.dlp.v2.InfoTypeSupportedBy
nit: Do we use caps in other places? We should be consistent with values we expect users to replace.

nodes.bodyText: The existing reformatted snippets weren't consistent with this. I updated all of them to use lowercase letters in the last commit, because project ids tend to be lowercase, but I can also make them all uppercase if needed

nodes.bodyText: Same here - please move filter and jobType to the sample
inlined these in the sample in 66b34ca
reformatted to use Assert.assertThat() in 66b34ca
This should be in a separate cleanup function with the After tag, so it still runs of the test fails.
moved this to a cleanup function in 66b34ca

If there isn't a job, we should make sure there is with a setUp function that creates one that runs first.
Or, alternatively make the test pass if no jobs are found.
I think the setUp approach is better, since the delete method is tested in the same class, and that has to have an existing job so that we can test it.

I think you were probably right the fist time and this should be a provided env var. More generally, any time we ask the user to provide a specific resources we should probably be asking for an environment variable in a test.
This probably applies to PUB_SUB_TOPIC_ID and PUB_SUB_SUBSCRIPTION_ID as well.
If you want to address this in this PR, I can walk you through how to set these during our next 1:1. If not, please open an issue and assign it to yourself and we'll fix at a later time.
Decided to keep the env vars. Let's go over how to set these for kokoro on Monday.

I think this pattern is going to introduce a race condition when this test is run in parallel. It's possible while each test is going to create a new job, they could both make a request and get the same job, which one might fail.
Additionally, JUNIT doesn't actually guarantee any specific order for tests. deletejobs could run after listjobs.
I think this means we have to do 2 things:

Update ListJobs to pass as long as the request was successful (even if it's empty)
Create a job with a specific UUID that the deleteJob can delete.

Made these changes! One interesting thing to note, after some debugging and inspecting in pantheon, i found out I had to append "i-" to the UUID string I generated in order to get deleteJob to work. Is this possibly a bug in the DlpJobName.of() method?
It could be - can you create a short script to show the issue and open an issue against the repo that contains it?
